import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import sklearn
from plotly import tools
import plotly.graph_objs as go
from IPython.core import display as ICD
from plotly.offline import init_notebook_mode, iplot
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
source.673cc031:
PATH = '../input/'
surveySchema = pd.read_csv(PATH + 'SurveySchema.csv')
freeFormResponses = pd.read_csv(PATH + 'freeFormResponses.csv')
multipleChoiceResponses = pd.read_csv(PATH + 'multipleChoiceResponses.csv', encoding='ISO-8859-1')
source.bf571c76:
gender_distribution = multipleChoiceResponses['Q1'].iloc[1:].value_counts()
ax = gender_distribution.plot('bar', figsize=(10,6), width=0.3,
                                rot=0, title='Gender Distribution')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(gender_distribution)))
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(np.round(p.get_height(),decimals=2), 
                (p.get_x()+p.get_width()/2., p.get_height()), 
                ha='center', va='center', xytext=(0, 10), 
                textcoords='offset points', fontsize=14, color='black')
source.5209e40d:
age_order = ['18-21', '22-24', '25-29', '30-34', '35-39', '40-44', '45-49', '50-54', '55-59', '60-69', '70-79', '80+']

age_distribution = multipleChoiceResponses['Q2'].iloc[1:].value_counts()
ax = age_distribution.loc[age_order].plot('bar', figsize=(15,6), rot=0, title='Age Distribution')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(age_distribution)))
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(np.round(p.get_height(),decimals=2), 
                (p.get_x()+p.get_width()/2., p.get_height()), 
                ha='center', va='center', xytext=(0, 10), 
                textcoords='offset points', fontsize=14, color='black')
source.502a14ec:
country_distribution = multipleChoiceResponses['Q3'].iloc[1:]
country_distribution = country_distribution.replace('United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland', 'United Kingdom of \n Great Britain and \n Northern Ireland')
country_distribution = country_distribution.replace('United States of America', 'United States of \n America').value_counts()[:10]

ax = country_distribution.plot('bar', figsize=(15,6), rot=0, title='Country distribution')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(country_distribution)))
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(np.round(p.get_height(),decimals=2), 
                (p.get_x()+p.get_width()/2., p.get_height()), 
                ha='center', va='center', xytext=(0, 10), 
                textcoords='offset points', fontsize=14, color='black')
source.fef11bd4:
type_of_education = ['Masterâs degree', 'Bachelorâs degree', 'Doctoral degree', 'Some college/university study without earning a bachelorâs degree', 'Professional degree', 'I prefer not to answer', 'No formal education past high school']
type_of_education_change = ['Masters \n degree', 'Bachelors \n degree', 'Doctoral \n degree', 'Some college/ \n university study \n without earning \n a bachelors degree', 'Professional \n degree', 'I prefer not \n to answer', 'No formal \n education past \n high school']

level_of_education = multipleChoiceResponses['Q4'].iloc[1:].value_counts()

for i in range(len(type_of_education)):
    level_of_education = level_of_education.replace(type_of_education[i], type_of_education_change[i])

ax = level_of_education.plot('bar', figsize=(15,6),rot=0, title='Distribution of level of formal education')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(level_of_education)))
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(np.round(p.get_height(),decimals=2), 
                (p.get_x()+p.get_width()/2., p.get_height()), 
                ha='center', va='center', xytext=(0, 10), 
                textcoords='offset points', fontsize=14, color='black')
source.0b3834f1:
undergraduate_major = multipleChoiceResponses['Q5'].iloc[1:].value_counts()

ax = undergraduate_major.plot('barh', figsize=(15,10),rot=0, fontsize=13,
                                title='Distribution of Undergraduate major field')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(undergraduate_major)))
for i in ax.patches:
    ax.text(i.get_width()+50, i.get_y()+.4, \
            str(round(i.get_width(), 2)), fontsize=15, color='black')
ax.invert_yaxis()

compensation = multipleChoiceResponses['Q9'].iloc[1:]
compensation = compensation.replace(multipleChoiceResponses['Q9'].iloc[1:][6], 
                     'I do not wish to disclose \n my yearly compensation')

ax = compensation.value_counts().plot('barh', figsize=(15,10),rot=0, fontsize=13,
                                            title='Current compensation')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(compensation.value_counts())))

for i in ax.patches:
    ax.text(i.get_width()+50, i.get_y()+.4, \
            str(round(i.get_width(), 2)), fontsize=15, color='black')
ax.invert_yaxis()
source.a0371c55:
type_of_usage = ['We are exploring ML methods (and may one day put a model into production)',
                'No (we do not use ML methods)',                                         
                'We recently started using ML methods (i.e., models in production for less than 2 years)',
                'We have well established ML methods (i.e., models in production for more than 2 years)',
                'We use ML methods for generating insights (but do not put working models into production)']

type_of_usage_change = ['We are exploring ML methods \n (and may one day put a model into production)',
                'No (we do not use ML methods)',                                         
                'We recently started using ML methods \n (i.e., models in production for less than 2 years)',
                'We have well established ML methods \n (i.e., models in production for more than 2 years)',
                'We use ML methods for generating insights \n (but do not put working models into production)']

machine_learning_usage = multipleChoiceResponses['Q10'].iloc[1:]
for i in range(len(type_of_usage)):
    machine_learning_usage = machine_learning_usage.replace(type_of_usage[i], type_of_usage_change[i])

ax = machine_learning_usage.value_counts().plot('barh', figsize=(15,8),rot=0, fontsize=15,
                                            title='Machine Learning usage in current employment')
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(years_of_experience.value_counts())))

for i in ax.patches:
    ax.text(i.get_width()+50, i.get_y()+.4, \
            str(round(i.get_width(), 2)), fontsize=15, color='black')
ax.invert_yaxis()

source.c2324862:
ml_library_preference = multipleChoiceResponses['Q20'].iloc[1:].value_counts()
labels = (np.array(ml_library_preference.index))
sizes = (np.array((ml_library_preference)))
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(ml_library_preference)))

trace = go.Pie(labels=labels, values=sizes, hole=0.6)
layout = go.Layout(
    title='Preference of ML library'
)
fig = go.Figure(data=[trace], layout=layout)
iplot(fig, filename="ml-library")

source.ddcbcb12:
percentage_of_ML = multipleChoiceResponses['Q46'].iloc[1:].value_counts()
labels = (np.array(percentage_of_ML.index))
sizes = (np.array((percentage_of_ML)))
print('Number of respondents: ' + str(sum(percentage_of_ML)))

trace = go.Pie(labels=labels, values=sizes, hole=0.6)
layout = go.Layout(
    title='percentage of Machine learning/Data Science is used in the projects'
)
fig = go.Figure(data=[trace], layout=layout)
iplot(fig, filename="percentage of Machine learning/Data Science is used in the projects")
source.4c69d1cc:
- Wahh!! This is awesome. Most of the respondants recommend Python language to start Data Science.
- Very few are recommending either C++, Matlab, Java or other langauges.
- In future, we can expect downfall in the usage of other programming languages in the field of Data Science.
source.a5e823e5:
### Analysis:
- Most of the respondents that are contributing to ML/Data science belong to United States of America.
- India is in the second place in terms of contributors, but the difference is very subtle.
source.4e2472e2: ## What percentage of Machine learning/Data Science is used in the projects?
source.3a1ab2a5: # <center>Insights of Kaggle ML and DS Survey</center>
source.2f8e79ca:
### Analysis:
- Python, R, SQL, Java are the top most programming languages used by Data Sciencts.
- Python is used by most of the respondents(nearly 8180). One of the reason might be that there are many libraries integrated with Python and it is easy to use.
- We know that Python and R are the most used languages for Data Science. Also, statistics are showing the same.
source.6c57ac3e:
### Analysis:
- 23859 people responded to this question(Q1).
- Out of them, 19430 are Male and 4010 are Female. There is a huge gender gap.
source.13cfc9d2:
### Analysis:
- Based on the previous statistics, we know that Python stands first in the usage of programming language and R stands second.
- In the same way, Matplotlib, library of Python is preferred more for plotting. Similarly, ggplot2, library of R language is preferred by R users for plotting.
- Seaborn comes next, which is developed on Matplotlib. 10.9% use Seaborn.
- Plotly is also getting popular nowadays and it takes time to become the most preferred one.
source.fcebb2ac:
### Analysis:
- It's very great that 5539 respondets, spend 50-74% of their time on Machine learning/Data Science.
- And 5015 respondents, spend 25-49% of their time on ML/DS. 
- There are very few(484 respondents) spend all the time on ML/DS. They might fond of Data Science very much.
source.8a1beeb2:
### Analysis:
- We all know that Scikit-learn, TensorFlow and Keras are the most used libraries.
- As we can see, it is also true statistically. 46.5% respondents use Scikit-Learn library, because it is very easy to use and train models.
- TensorFlow is the recent deeplearning library and 15% of the respondents prefer it.
- 13.3% of the respondents use Keras. Keras is also a deep learning library that can be used to train deep learning models and very easy to learn.
source.877ac330:
### This dataset is very interesting. I came to know about the statistics of real world.
### Please do UPVOTE this kernel if you find this content useful.
source.365eb3f6: ## How long have they been writing code to analyze data?
source.fd7170f1:
### Insights:
-  If we observe, the usage of Machine learning is very less in the projects for most of the respondents. Then, there is no use of learning and spending alot of time in learning.
- 11.7% of the respondents don't use at all. This is so sad.
- Around 50% of the respondents said that their projects involve 30% of Machine learning. This is very good to hear.
source.ed4c093e:
### Analysis:
- 53.4% of the respondents have been writing code for 0-2 years. This is very nice. Most of them are learning and Machine learning has reached to many people.
- 4.3% of the respondents have never written code but they want to learn. This is very great to hear from them.
- 0.221%(41) of the respondents have never written code and don't want to learn DS. They should chose some other career in the near future. 
- If you don't have the zeal to learn, it's waste of time to learn Data Science.
source.52ad1087: ## Usage of Machine learning in employement
source.3ad1190f:
### Analysis:
- Most of the respondents who are contributing to the area Data Science hold "Masters degree".
- Next place goes to "Bachelors degree".
- Due to the hype of Data Science and increase in MOOC's, 232 respondents are able to contribute to this area with no formal education past high school. We should really appreciate their commitment towards Data Science. We should think this as an achievement as a community.
source.2935c3aa:
### Insights:
- Out of 20185 respondents, 4756 respondents don't want to disclose thier yearly compensation.
- Another 4398 respondents are earning 0-10,000.
- If we observe the graph carefully, as the compensation increases, the number of respondents to that compensation decreases.
- Very few(23) are getting compensation of 400-500,000.
source.f461999e:
### Insights:
- Most of them are exploring Machine Learning methods. They are in learning stage only.
- It is very sad to know that 4411 respodants don't use ML methods. They are wasting their valuable knowledge.
- It's very great to know that 3790 respondents havr started using Machine learning models in production. The aim of the data science is to help people around us and increase customer experience by using the power of Machine learning.
source.8b09b16b:
### Analysis:
- Most of the respondents are students. With the increase of MOOCs, students are able to learn quickly at their own pace.
- Obviously, Data Scientists contribute because they are data scientists.
- The roles in the decreasing order based on the respondents current role:
    - Student > Data Scientist > Software Engineer > Data Analyst > Research Scientist > Not employed.
- 842 respondents who are contributing to this field are "Not employed". This is so sad. Hope they will find a job soon!!
- As we see, the roles are in various domain, they are not bounded to a specific domain. We can clearly state that we can apply Data Science in any domain.
source.b934c1e9:
### Insights:
- Most of the respondents who are contributing to ML/Data Science belong to Computer science and Engineering(non-computer focused).  This makes sense because Computer science students always work on some technologies and in a similar way they started learning Data Science too.
- As we know, Data Science is full of statistics. It is very good to see Mathematicians/Statisticians in third place. 2950 of them are statisticians. Also, they can learn/grasp things very easily.
- The people from different backgrounds are also contributing to Data Science field.
source.d07e6361: ## Which programming language is better for a newbie?
source.ea1b8862:
### Insights:
- Out of 21101 respondents, 5898 respondents have only 0-1 years of experience. We can say that most of them are have started learning recently.
- Order of "Years of Experience" based on the response:
    - (0-1) > (1-2) > (2-3) > (5-10)
- If we observe, there are some respondents who have experience more than 20 years. We can say that, Data Science is not new. It has become popular now a days because of availability of high computational power and availability of data.
source.5ee3d453:
- Thank you Kaggle for providing the dataset. It is very interesting to know insights from these types of datasets.
- Let's explore each question and analyze them.
source.3619d394:
### Analysis:
- Age distribution: (25-29) > (22-24) > (30-34) > (18-21) > (35-39) > (40-44)
- Most of the data scientists/contributing to data science are of age 25-29.
- There are a few respondents contributing to ML/Data Science whose age is above 80 are 39. Even at this stage, they are very much interested to explore this new area.
